reporting-org.narrative: Promundo is a global leader in promoting gender justice and preventing violence by engaging men and boys in partnership with women and girls. We believe that working with men and boys to transform harmful gender norms and unequal power dynamics is a critical part of the solution to achieve gender equality. For the empowerment of women and girls to continue advancing, men and boys must see themselves as allies in the process. Men and boys also benefit when harmful norms are challenged. Our research, programs, and advocacy efforts show that promoting healthy masculinity (or positive notions of “what it means to be a man”) and femininity (or “what is means to be a woman”) leads to improvements in men’s own lives, and in the lives of women and girls.

title.narrative: Prevention+ Middle East North Africa (MENA)

description.narrative: Prevention+ aims to address gender inequality by promoting masculinities based on equality, non-violence and care-giving, and by focusing on boys and men, and girls and women, as agents of change. The long-term objectives of this five-year program are to contribute to a gender just society which is free of gender-based violence (GBV). Prevention+ aims to transform social norms that drive GBV, and contribute to related changes in legislation, policies and practices of governments and other service providers. Rutgers, Promundo, and Sonke Gender Justice, along with local partners, will work with institutions and male and female adolescents and adults across Indonesia, Pakistan, Uganda, Rwanda and selected MENA countries. Women’s rights organizations are essential partners of this program to support activities and advocate for change. The MenEngage Alliance will further promote Prevention+ objectives internationally through its network and policy advocacy. The program is evidence-based; it has been developed on the basis of research findings that show that well-designed gender-transformative programs with both sexes of different age groups are highly effective in order to underpin the positive transformation of rigid gender norms, and contribute to a society free of GBV. Prevention+ is funded by the Government of the Netherlands.

title.narrative: Result Area 2: OUTCOME: Increased supportive norms to prevent GBV and promote gender justice
2.1 Increased positive notions of manhood (equitable, non-violent and caring) among (young) men and women in the targeted communities

comment.narrative: In 2019 19% of participants increased positive notions of manhood (the percentage was 66% in the baseline to increase and attain 85%)

title.narrative: Result Area 1: OUTCOME: (Young) men and women have more gender just attitudes and behavior

1.1 % of participating (young) men and women have more positive attitudes, including acceptance of positive masculinities (including equitable, non-violent, caregiving) and of women’s political and economic participation

comment.narrative:
In 2018 27% of participating (young) men and women have more positive attitudes, including acceptance of positive masculinities (including equitable, non-violent, caregiving) and of women’s political and economic participation (the percentage was 41% in the baseline to decrease and attain 14%). This percentage reflects the answers of men and women that agree that men should be tough and violent to get respect.
In 2019 25% of participating (young) men and women have more positive attitudes, including acceptance of positive masculinities (including equitable, non-violent, caregiving) and of women’s political and economic participation (the percentage was 58% in the baseline to increase and attain 83%). This percentage reflects the answers of men and women that disagree that men should be the ones to bring money, on how often they share feelings and worries.

title.narrative: 1.2 Improved communication skills within % of the participating couples

comment.narrative:
In 2018 22% of the participating couples improved communication skills (the percentage was 63% in the baseline to increase and attain 85%).
In 2019 the improvement is 28% (the percentage was 47% in the baseline to increase and attain 75%).

title.narrative: 1.4 Improved ability of % of participating (young) men to cope with problems and to control their aggression and frustration (e.g. reducing alcohol abuse)

comment.narrative:
In 2018 26% of participating (young) men improved ability of to cope with problems and to control their aggression and frustration (the percentage was 51% in the baseline to increase and attain 77%).
In 2019 the number is 17% (77% in the baseline and 94% in the endline)

title.narrative: 1.3 % participating (young) men and women who do not believe intimate partner violence is acceptable

comment.narrative:
In 2018 30% of the participants changed their attitudes to not believing intimate partner violence is acceptable (51% of the participants in the baseline agree that there are times where women deserves to be beaten and should tolerate violence to keep the family together, this number decreases to 21% in the endline).
In 2019 17% participating (young) men and women changed their attitudes to not believing intimate partner violence is acceptable (the percentage was 77% in the baseline to increase and attain 94%)"

title.narrative: 1.6 % of (young) men and women report positive changes towards more equitable decision-making patterns (e.g. on household economics)

comment.narrative:
In 2018 42% of (young) men and women report positive changes towards more equitable decision-making patterns (the percentage was 32% in the baseline to increase and attain 73%).
In 2019 30% of (young) men and women report positive changes towards more equitable decision-making patterns (the percentage was 31% in the baseline to increase and attain 61%).

title.narrative: 1.5 Reduced levels of intimate partner violence among % of participants

comment.narrative:
In 2018 8% of participants reduced levels of intimate partner violence (in the baseline 36% of women reported experiencing an act of physical, emotional and economic intimate partner violence at least once in the last month, the number decreases and attain 28% in the endline)
In 2019 24% of participants reduced levels of intimate partner violence (in the baseline 52% of the participants were thinking men shouldn't act strong even if they feel scared or nervous inside and shouldn't use violence to get respect if necessary, the number is 76% in the endline)

title.narrative: Result Area 4: OUTCOME: Increased awareness, support, capacity, collaboration and uptake of gender transformative approaches to engage (young) men and women in GBV prevention amongst networks, movements and organisations

RESULT AREA 3: OUTCOME: More CSOs and relevant public sectors have institutionalized gender transformative approaches.
3.4 Improved referral and/or response mechanisms for survivors of GBV

comment.narrative: Anecdotal reflections and qualitative conversations with 9 members of MOSA staff (Ministry of Social Affairs) who participated in trainings indicate improved referral. Furthermore we know from running ABAAD's Men's Center that several newly referred beneficiaries came to us due to these training processes.

title.narrative: Result Area 3: OUTCOME: Improved quality of GBV programming and services provided to (young) women and men within the public and CSO sector
3.1 More favourable attitudes towards gender equity among % of trained government and CSO staff

comment.narrative: Anecdotal reflections and qualitative conversations with 9 members of MOSA staff (Ministry of Social Affairs) who participated in trainings indicate that while these trainings had somewhat smaller scope than originally intended due to revolution, roadblocks, and simultaneous economic crisis, our team did nonetheless achieve positive progress and reflections from the MOSA staff who did attend trainings. This feedback is limited to quotes and anecdotal impressions, as the sample is rather small and no pre and post tests were conducted with this group.

title.narrative: 3.2 More favourable attitudes towards engaging (young) men in GBV prevention among trained government and CSO staff

comment.narrative: Anecdotal reflections and qualitative conversations with 9 members of MOSA staff (Ministry of Social Affairs) who participated in trainings indicate that while these trainings had somewhat smaller scope than originally intended due to revolution, roadblocks, and simultaneous economic crisis, our team did nonetheless achieve positive progress and reflections from the MOSA staff who did attend trainings. This feedback is limited to quotes and anecdotal impressions, as the sample is rather small and no pre and post tests were conducted with this group.

title.narrative: 3.3 Increased comfort and skills in trained government and CSO staff in working with (young) men to prevent GBV

comment.narrative: Anecdotal reflections and qualitative conversations with 9 members of MOSA staff (Ministry of Social Affairs) who participated in trainings indicate that while these trainings had somewhat smaller scope than originally intended due to revolution, roadblocks, and simultaneous economic crisis, our team did nonetheless achieve positive progress and reflections from the MOSA staff who did attend trainings. This feedback is limited to quotes and anecdotal impressions, as the sample is rather small and no pre and post tests were conducted with this group.
